Title: Our Workflow with Blender and Godot - Blender Studio
Description: For DOGWALK we set up a pipeline between Blender and Godot. Here is how we did it.

Title: ¬ª Bullfrog in the Dungeon The Digital Antiquarian
Description: In January of 1995, Electronic Arts bought the prestigious British games studio Bullfrog Productions for an undisclosed sum that was rumored to be in the neighborhood of $45 million. The lives of the 35 or so people who worked at Bullfrog were transformed overnight. Peter Molyneux, the man who had build the studio‚Äôs reputation on the back of his ‚Äúgod game‚Äù Populous six years earlier, woke up the morning after the contract was signed with real money to spend for the first time in his life. For him and his colleagues, the new situation was gratifying, but also vaguely unsettling.

Title: New trend: extreme hours at AI startups
Description: Pulling 80+ hour work weeks ‚Äì including weekends ‚Äì is becoming the norm across AI startups, and is unlikely to stop while AI is so hot.

Title: The Making of Walker (DMA Design) - Ian Dunlop & Neill Glancy Interview -  Amiga Classic
Description:
Walker is a classic 2D shooter with the side-scrolling from the right to the left. Player takes control of gigantic robot AG-9 (codename Walker). The mission is simple - guide Walker through the four time zones and kill everybody/destroy everything. 

Learn how DMA Design and Psygnosis created Walker with this exclusive interview with the games creators Ian Dunlop and Neill Glancy. Ian and Neill helped create some of Psygnosis and DMA Design's best ever games, such as Walker.

If you ever wanted to learn how the Amiga classic Walker was created, check out this interview today.

While listening to how Walker and other classic titles were made, please enjoy this part playthrough of Walker. 

Please check out the Arcade Attack homepage for all our retro reviews, podcasts, interviews and lots more: https://www.arcadeattack.co.uk/

Fancy discussing this video? Fancy suggesting a topic of conversation? Please tweet us @arcadeattackUK or catch us on facebook.com/arcadeattackUK.

Please also consider subscribing to the Arcade Attack Retro Gaming podcast on your favourite podcast platform. We are on Apple Podcasts, Spotify, Google Podcasts and all your other favourite platforms - here is a handy link:

https://link.chtbl.com/kW1KLYuH

on Linux and BSD.

Title: Typing to Think, Speaking to Prompt
Description:
My earlier post about the rise of voice as a UI had me pondering what exactly is it that makes voice input ideal in some circumstances and entirely undesired in others. Spoken language is faster per word and, in a naive economic sense, ‚Äúbetter‚Äù1. And yet, there are times where I have no interest in ‚Äúgoing fast‚Äù. Why?
This topic makes me think of Andy Clark‚Äôs Supersizing the Mind, which opens with a famous Feynman quote about insisting that his ‚Äúdaily notes‚Äù were not simply a record of his activities but his actual thinking:

Title: Document.write
GPT-5 Router - Inevitable Future of Chat Interfaces

Title: Is MCP just a WSDL Reboot for LLMs?
Description: If the Model Context Protocol gives you 2005 vibes, you‚Äôre not imagining it. MCP feels like the good part of the old web-services dream brought forward for AI agents: describe what you can do, let a generic client discover it, and integrate without bespoke glue. That was the pitch behind WSDL in the Web 2.0 era‚ÄîWeb Services Description Language‚Äîan XML contract where a service declared its operations, messages, and types so tools could generate clients automatically. If you‚Äôve never seen it, the original specs still read like a time capsule: WSDL 1.1 and WSDL 2.0.

Title: The Death of the IDE? - Zed Blog
Description: From the Zed Blog: Steve Yegge and Nathan Sobo debate whether IDEs are obsolete in the AI era. Their opposing perspectives reveal surprising common ground.

Title: The fixed length bottleneck and the feed forward network
Description: The feed-forward network in an LLM processes context vectors one at a time. This feels like it would cause similar issues to the old fixed-length bottleneck, even though it almost certainly does not.

His reply came swiftly:

Title: I wanted to take more pictures, so I vibecoded a portfolio
Description:
Warning: English is not my native language and I refused to ask an LLM to write this for me, so at least you got a somewhat human blogpost in exchange for some bad english :P
I‚Äôve had an interest in photography for a long time, I remember being fascinated by it in highschool and since then I still enjoy looking at pictures, reading about photography (suffering from GAS) and most of all, taking pictures.

Title: Why I Quit Competitive Programming
Description: TL;DR # I tried competitive programming for a whole year and it didn‚Äôt work out well for me, I didn‚Äôt enjoy it and didn‚Äôt achieve anything remarkable as well. So it‚Äôs better to take the L and move on and try other things I wanted to try, but I couldn‚Äôt because of competitive programming. For the rest of the article I‚Äôm going to talk about the sunk cost fallacy.

Title: Lasso Transactions as an alternative to Copyright
Description:
Often, people who oppose copyright give weak
                  excuses as for how a market would sustain artists
                  creating work, without the government creating an
                  artificial monopoly on said work. In a recent
                  conversation with one of my friends who also oppose
                  many aspects of the current copyright system, we
                  brainstormed alternatives. I opposed the traditional
                  donation model as it‚Äôs highly subject to free-rider
                  problem, and demanded that a new model be
                  created1, if we should
                  reasonably expect to convince people to oppose
                  copyright.
